questions.text: Which of the given instrument's tip resembles the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rampley's Sponge Holding Forceps

Explanation:

Rampley's Sponge Holding Forceps are designed with tips that have a specific shape ideal for gripping sponges or swabs securely. These tips often feature serrations.

Rampley's Sponge Holding Forceps (Option B) ​

  • Designed in a scissor-like configuration, featuring ratcheted handles with serrated looped jaws.
  • Used to handle gauze or sponges.
  • Used to hold gall bladder/cervix/tongue, etc. during operative procedures.

Mayo's Towel Clip (Option A ruled out) ​

  • Cross-action tip: no approximation.
  • Used to secure drapes in the surgical area.
  • Used to attach suction tubes, diathermy wires, and laparoscopic cables to the operating table.
  • Used to stabilise ribs in cases of flail chest.

 

Doyen's Towel Clip (Option D ruled out) ​

  • A short instrument with curved ends with sharp points.
  • The handles connect at the proximal ends.
  • Tension blades open when pressed and vice versa.

 

Moynihan's Tetra-Towel clip (Option C ruled out) ​

  • Has two teeth on each blade.
  • Attaches cut edges of a skin incision to the corners of draped tetra towels to isolate the surgical area.
  • Alternatively, isolation can be done by suturing the draped edges to subcutaneous tissue or using an adhesive plastic drape with a pre-made incision.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

choices.text: The needle holder is sterilized by an autoclave.
Toothed dissecting forceps are used to hold delicate structures like nerves and vessels.
Curved needle holders provide better maneuverability in deep areas like the pelvis.
Plain non-toothed dissecting forceps are used to hold friable structures like peritoneum and tendons.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Toothed dissecting forceps are used to hold delicate structures like nerves and vessels.

 

Explanation:

INSTRUMENT

DESCRIPTION

NEEDLE HOLDER FORCEPS
  • Small distal blades with criss-cross serrations and a groove for grip.
  • Length of handle: Blade Ratio: 4:1.
  • Types: Straight or curved
  • Needle Positioning: Needle held at the junction of proximal 2/3 and distal 1/3 for control.
  • Handling: Held between thumb and ring finger.
  • Curved Holders: For better maneuverability in deep areas (pelvis, thorax). (Option C ruled out)
  • Sterilization: Autoclave. (Option A ruled out)
  • Tungsten-Carbide Coating: Increases durability.

PLAIN DISSECTING FORCEPS


 
  • Used to hold delicate, soft, and friable structures like peritoneum, vessels, bowel, nerves, and tendons. (Option D ruled out)
  • Not suitable for holding skin or tough structures.
  • Hold, fix, steady, or stretch tissues.
  • Hold and cauterize small bleeding vessels.

TOOTHED FORCEPS
  • Used to hold skin and tough structures like fascia and aponeurosis.
  • Not used for delicate structures like the bowel, vessels, or nerves. (Option B)
  • May have one-in-two or two-in-three teeth.
  • Adson’s Forceps: Small, fine forceps for delicate work; can be toothed or non-toothed.
  • Victor–Bonney’s Forceps: Heavy-toothed dissecting forceps.

questions.text:
Match the following instruments with their corresponding images:

 


	
		
			
			1)
			
			
			a) Bone nibbler
			
		
		
			
			2)
			
			
			b) Humby’s Knife
			
		
		
			
			3)
			
			
			c) Rib Shear
			
		
		
			
			4)
			
			
			d) Bone Cutter
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

Explanation:

 

INSTRUMENT

DESCRIPTION

HUMBY’S KNIFE
  • Used for harvesting split skin grafts, usually from the thigh.
  • Parts: Stout handle with two flat blades, one fixed and one rotatable.
  • Disposable blade is secured with knobs for grafting.
  • Firm pressure with sawing action is used for skin harvesting.
  • Punctate bleeding confirms a successful graft.
  • Graft placed on a sterile board with small cuts to prevent seroma.
  • Fixed to the recipient site with sutures or staples.
  • Inspected on the 5th day for graft take-up.
  • The donor site is inspected after 10 days and left open.
  • Graft stages: plasmatic imbibition, revascularization, circulation.

RIB SHEAR
  • Large rough handles for better grip.
  • One blade is blunt with grooves and serrations, used as a protector for adjacent tissues.
  • The other blade is sharp and cuts the rib.
  • Designed to cut the rib from the front.
  • Used specifically for rib resection.

BONE / RIB CUTTER
  • Short blades with sharp, firm cutting edges for cutting bones.
  • Stout handle with ridges for a firm grip.
  • Provides optimal mechanical force for cutting bones or bone spurs.
  • Some models include a leverage system for enhanced performance.

BONE NIBBLER
  • Sharp edges at the tip with concave blades.
  • Available in single action or double action joint.
  • Used to nibble bone into pieces.
  • Commonly used in craniectomy, rib resection, and small bone amputations.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presents with rectal bleeding and a history of hemorrhoids. His physician decides to perform a proctoscopy using Kelly's rectal speculum to assess the cause of the bleeding. Which of the following is NOT an indication of the use of Kelly's rectal speculum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)Treating acute anal fissure

 

Explanation:

Kelly's rectal speculum is contraindicated in cases of acute anal fissure due to the potential for exacerbating the patient's pain and causing further injury.

Kelly's Rectal Speculum

Indications:

Diagnostic:

  • Piles (Option A ruled out)
  • Fissure in ano
  • Polyps
  • Stricture
  • Internal opening in fistula
  • Carcinoma or any rectal bleeding (Option D ruled out)

Therapeutic:

  • Injection therapy for partial prolapse or piles (Option B ruled out)
  • Cryotherapy for piles
  • Banding for piles
  • Polypectomy
  • Biopsy for carcinoma rectum or anorectum.

 

Contraindications: Acute anal fissures (Option C)

Parts:

  • Shape: Conical, with a larger proximal diameter (3.5 cm) than the distal (2.5 cm) for better light reflection.
  • Length: Typically 10 cm.
  • Obturator: Inner part that facilitates easy insertion.

Proximal Flange: Funnel-shaped, 5 cm in diameter

Positions for Proctoscopy

questions.text: A 45 year old woman undergoes surgery for varicose veins involving the stripping of the long saphenous vein using a Mayo vein stripper. Post-operatively, she complains of pain and tingling along the medial aspect of her leg. Which nerve is most commonly damaged during the stripping of the long saphenous vein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Saphenous nerve

Explanation:

The saphenous nerve runs along the path of the long saphenous vein and is susceptible to injury during stripping procedures, leading to saphenous neuralgia.

MAYO VEIN STRIPPER:

 

Mayo Vein Stripper

Uses:

  • Primarily used for removal of varicose veins, typically the long saphenous vein.
  • Employed when the vein is severely damaged, often due to varicose veins.

Procedure:

  • Insertion: The Mayo vein stripper is passed through an incision made just below the saphenofemoral junction.
  • Stripping: The instrument is threaded through the vein, usually stripping up to the middle of the leg.
  • Ligation: The damaged vein is tied off (ligated) or completely removed, depending on the condition of the vein.

Complications:

  • Saphenous neuralgia (nerve pain).
  • Saphenous nerve injury is the most common complication after surgical treatment of varicose veins.

Endothermal ablation

  • The endothermal ablation procedure involves threading a small laser fibre into the vein at the failure location.
  • Following local anesthesia, blood flow is obstructed by irritating the vein wall and allowing the vein to close. The vein eventually disappears and is no longer visible on the surface of the leg.
  • There are two types of endothermal ablation: endovenous laser ablation (EVLA) and radiofrequency ablation (RFA)

 

Sciatic nerve (Option A): Unlikely to be damaged as it runs posteriorly in the thigh, far from the saphenous vein.

Tibial nerve(Option B): Unlikely to be affected since it is located in the posterior compartment of the leg, not near the saphenous vein.

Femoral nerve(Option D): Unlikely to be damaged during this procedure as it is located in the groin and anterior thigh, away from the path of the saphenous vein.

questions.text:
Match the following instruments with their respective images:


 


	
		
			
			1. Kocher’s forceps
			
			
			A) 
			
		
		
			
			2. Mosquito forceps
			
			 
			B) 
			
		
		
			
			3. Allis forceps
			
			
			C) 
			
		
		
			
			4. Babcock’s forceps
			
			
			D)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A)1-A,2-B,3-C,4-D

 

Explanation:

Kocher’s Forceps:

  • Serrations in the distal blades with an opposing tooth at the tip.
  • Holds tissues or pedicles securely, preventing slippage and retraction of vessels or bleeders.
  • Types:
    • Straight/Curved.
    • Small/medium/large.
  • Used in thyroidectomy, hemorrhoidectomy, mastectomy, polypectomy, and hysterectomy.
  • Used to secure tough or fibrous tissues in areas like the palms, soles, and scalp to prevent vessel retraction during surgery.
  • Holds gauze and gauze pellets.

Mosquito Forceps:

Features

  • Distal blades have transverse serrations for a firm grip.
  • The proximal part includes a locking mechanism.

Uses

  • Hemostasis: Catching bleeding points during surgery.
  • Surgical Manipulation: Opening facial planes, passing ligatures, holding fascia, peritoneum, or sutures.
  • Abscess Drainage: Used like sinus forceps to drain abscesses.
  • Appendix Surgery: Crushing the base of the appendix.
  • Circumcision: Catching prepuceal skin.
  • Catheter Clamping: Clamping a catheter between the hinge and ratchet.
  • Specialized Surgeries: Mosquito forceps (Halsted) are used in pediatric surgery, microsurgery, cleft surgery, and plastic surgery.

Babcock’s Forceps:

 

  • Distal blades are curved with triangular fenestra, allowing soft tissues to bulge out.
  • Non-traumatic tip with transverse serrations and a ratchet mechanism.
  • Used to hold bowel, fallopian tubes, appendix, urinary bladder, ureter, spermatic cord, and lymph nodes.

Alli’s tissue-holding forceps:

  • Distal blades do not oppose each other; the tip has opposing teeth in each straight blade.
  • Equipped with a ratchet mechanism.
  • Used to hold skin flaps, fascia, fibrous tissue, aponeurosis, galea (in craniotomy), and bladder wall.
  • Essential instrument in both major and minor surgeries; available in small, medium, and large sizes.
  • Large Allis is used in hysterectomy to hold the vaginal wall and tough structures.
  • Not recommended for holding delicate structures like bowel or vessel walls.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to retract the scapula during thoracotomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B)


 

Explanation:

This instrument is known as a scapula retractor. It has got a long stout handle with a broad right-angled blade with serrations.

  • It is used to retract scapula during thoracotomy

Balfour self-retaining retractor (Option A ruled out):

  • Features adjustable blades for retracting the abdominal wall and tissues during surgery.
  • Quadrangular metal frame with two heavy, hook-shaped side blades designed to fit into the wound sides.
  • Includes a detachable third blade for retracting viscera.
  • One side blade has a screw to adjust the retraction width, while the detachable blade is fixed through an adjustable screw with a slot.
  • Inserted closed into the wound, then widened as needed

 

Beckman Weitlaner retractor (Option D ruled out):

  • The Beckman Weitlaner Retractor is a surgical tool that retracts tissues and skin during surgical procedures.
  • It is most commonly used during spinal and hip surgeries.
  • The instrument features finger ring handles along with a self-locking mechanism

 

Scapula retractor (Option B): 

  • It has got a long stout handle with a broad right-angled blade with serrations.
  • It is used to retract the scapula during thoracotomy.

Allison Lung retractor (Option C ruled out):

  • Long handle with light blade.
  • The blade is made up of wires. The blade is at right angle to the handle.
  • It is used to retract the lungs. The lung can expand between the wires of the blade.
  • It is atraumatic.
  • It is used in esophageal surgery, thoracic sympathectomy, and mediastinal surgery.

Bladder neck retractor:

  • It is a thin, long instrument with two thin long distal blades.
  • Proximal thin shafts have got a ratchet. When the ratchet closes, the blades will open.
  • It is used in retracting the bladder neck in bladder surgeries.

Correct Answer: B) Potts bulldog clamp

Explanation:
Doyen’s intestinal occlusion clamp (Option C ruled out):

  • Have diagonal serrations with opposing blades
  • Used to grasp and enclose delicate structures such as the intestines.
  • These instruments are used to occlude the lumen of the intestine and the blood vessels
  • The instrument has slightly concave jaws; therefore both ends meet only at the extreme when locked.
  • The lumen of the intestine or vessels lies in the center of concavity ensuring sustained pressure which is just enough to occlude the lumen but not damage it.

Payr’s gastric occlusion clamp (Option A ruled out):

  • It has longitudinal serrations on the inner surface of the blades with several ball-like projections along the sides which interlock each other of the opposite blade to have a firm grip on the stomach/bowel while using.
  • Once applied, it crushes the bowel.


Light’s Bulldog clamp (Option D ruled out):

  • Operates with a pinch cock mechanism to open and close.
  • Features fine transverse serrations on the blades.
  • Used to clamp vessels during vascular anastomosis, such as in AV fistula creation.
  • Provides a firm grip on the vessel without causing injury or slippage.


Potts bulldog clamp (Option B):

Resembles a paper clip with strong jaws and serrations, equipped with a spring-loaded handle for a secure vessel grip.

Uses:

  • Clamps vessels during vascular anastomosis (e.g., creating AV fistula in renal failure patients).
  • Used in major vessel surgeries involving the aorta, inferior vena cava, and portal vein.
  • Provides a firm grip that blocks the vessel without causing injury or slippage.
  • Specifically used for large vessels like the aorta and vena cava.


Satinsky Vascular clamp:

 

  • It is a light atraumatic long instrument with C-shaped distal blades which has fine teeth within.
  • It has a ratchet.
  • It can be applied to part of the circumference of the vessel in the portal vein, iliac veins, and inferior vena cava while removing tumour thrombus in renal cell carcinoma, in pancreatectomy, and major vessel surgeries.
  • Vascular anastomosis can be done using it.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates Mayo scissors from Metzenbaum scissors?

choices.text: Mayo scissors are designed for delicate dissection while Metzenbaum scissors are sturdy and suited for cutting dense tissues.
Mayo scissors are sturdy and suitable for cutting dense tissues, while Metzenbaum scissors are ideal for blunt dissection and fine tissue work.
Metzenbaum scissors are used for cutting dense tissues, while Mayo scissors are for blunt dissection in thoracic surgeries.
Metzenbaum scissors are suitable for cutting sutures and are sturdy, whereas Mayo scissors are delicate and used for blunt dissection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mayo scissors are sturdy and suitable for cutting dense tissues, while Metzenbaum scissors are ideal for blunt dissection and fine tissue work.

Explanation:

Mayo scissors are designed to handle dense and tough tissues, making them suitable for procedures like appendectomy and mastectomy. Metzenbaum scissors, on the other hand, are designed for more delicate tasks such as blunt dissection and cutting fine tissues.

 

Scissors Type

Design

Uses

Alternative Names

Mayo Scissors

Sturdy and robust, suitable for cutting dense tissues.
  • Appendectomy.
  • Herniotomy.
  • Exploratory laparotomy.
  • Mastectomy.
  • Gynecological surgeries (e.g., dissecting tendons, and uterus structures).
  • Cutting ligaments (e.g., laryngectomy, thyroidectomy).

Often called "suture scissors".

Metzenbaum Scissors

Delicate and ideal for blunt dissection.
  • Blunt dissection.
  • Incising deep rib bed periosteum in thoracic procedures.
  • Tonsillectomy

Commonly known as "Metz" or "Lahey forceps".

Lister Bandage Scissors

Features a longer, blunt-tipped bottom blade paired with an angled sharp upper blade for secure and precise cutting.
  • Cutting bandages on the skin.
  • Dressings.

questions.solution:

Explanation:

The Veress needle is specifically designed to establish pneumoperitoneum by creating a space in the abdominal cavity for laparoscopic procedures. It uses a sharp outer bevel to penetrate the abdominal wall and a blunt inner stylet to prevent injury to internal organs.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the safety protocols for electrosurgery using diathermy?

choices.text: Always use the maximum current setting to ensure effectiveness and minimize burns.
Bipolar diathermy is preferred in patients with implants.
Monopolar diathermy is preferred near vital & sensitive structures.
There is no need to use smoke extractors as the risk of exposure to surgical smoke is minimal.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bipolar diathermy is preferred in patients with implants.

Explanation:

Bipolar diathermy is preferred in sensitive areas and for patients with implanted devices because it limits the current flow to the tissue between the two active electrodes, thus reducing the risk of unintended burns and ensuring a more controlled application.

 

Monopolar Diathermy

  • Mechanism: Electrical current flows from a single electrode (diathermy pencil) through the target tissue and returns via a large surface plate (indifferent electrode).
  • Applications: Used for cutting and coagulation in various surgeries.
  • Hazards
    • Inadequate Contact: Poor contact with the indifferent electrode can cause burns.
    • Accidental Earthing: Touching metal objects can create unintended current pathways, leading to burns.
    • Insulation Failure: Damaged insulation on leads can cause burns.
    • Accidental Activation: Unintentional activation or contact with metal instruments can result in burns.

Bipolar Diathermy:

  • Mechanism: Uses two active electrodes (forceps, scissors) with current flowing between them, heating only the tissue between the tips. No indifferent electrode is needed.
  • Applications: Ideal for operating near vital structures and for patients with implanted devices. (Option C ruled out)
  • Advantages: Enhanced safety by localizing current and reducing the risk of unintended burns.

Key Considerations for Safe Electrosurgery

  • Equipment Check: Verify settings before use.
  • Lowest Effective Setting: Use minimal current necessary. (Option A ruled out)
  • Caution with Metal Objects: Be careful near other metal instruments.
  • Intermittent Use: Apply in short, controlled bursts.
  • Bipolar Preference: Prefer bipolar in sensitive areas or for patients with implants. (Option B)
  • Smoke Evacuation: Use smoke extractors to reduce exposure to surgical smoke. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the given instrument?

choices.text: Uses pressure and continuous bipolar energy for vessel sealing.
Achieves burst pressures over three times the normal systolic blood pressure.
Denatures collagen and elastin in vessel walls, forming a solid tissue seal.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sealing time is 8-10 seconds.

 

Explanation:

The given image is that of Ligasure. The sealing time is 2 to 4 seconds per seal.

LigaSure:

  • Technology:
    • Uses pressure and continuous bipolar energy for vessel sealing. (Option A ruled out)
    • Available for both laparoscopic and open surgeries since 1998.
  • Mechanism:
    • Applies high mechanical compression and adjusts energy delivery.
    • Denatures collagen and elastin in vessel walls, forming a solid tissue seal upon cooling. (Option D ruled out)
  • Efficiency:
    • Sealing time: Quick - 2 to 4 seconds per seal. (Option C)
    • Achieves burst pressures over three times the normal systolic blood pressure. (Option B ruled out)
    • Enhances reliability and consistency in surgical procedures.

Advantages:

  • Reduced Blood Loss: Significantly decreases operative blood loss and procedure time compared to traditional sutures and clips.
  • Enhanced Safety: Features feedback-controlled technology that stops energy delivery when the seal is complete, minimizing risk to surrounding tissues.

 

Applications:

  • Surgical Use: Effective in surgeries involving vascular pedicles (e.g., myomectomy, hysterectomy) and hemorrhoidectomy, thyroidectomies & open GI surgeries,
